AI.callerid_rules: No special caller ID or prefix rules (general anti-fraud norms apply)
AI.recent_changes: No recent changes; telemarketing remains largely unregulated
AI.regime_b2c_text: No specific telemarketing legislation; general law offers minimal consumer protection
AI.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing regulation found
AI.notes_for_product: Apply basic courtesy rules; treat any Anguilla calling as opt-out (stop if consumer objects). Consider consumer quiet hours as a precaution.

sources.title: N/A (No official sources on telemarketing; Lex Mundi (secondary) notes no consumer framework)

BM.callerid_rules: No special prefix; caller must provide identity if asked. No number spoofing allowed (standard truth-in-caller-ID principles)
BM.recent_changes: Personal Information Protection Act amendments effective 2025. New guidance on direct marketing issued 2025 (no major legislative changes otherwise)
BM.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing to consumers is regulated under personal data laws (PIPA 2016) and telecom rules (ECA 2011). Consumers have the right to opt out of marketing use of their data
BM.regime_b2b_text: Similar treatment as B2C – PIPA and Electronic Transactions rules apply to personal data in B2B context (no special B2B exemption)
BM.notes_for_product: Ensure an opt-out mechanism on all calls. No DNC list to scrub, but honor any request to stop. Consider mirroring typical calling hours. Automated dialers should not be used without consent. Record calls only with notice or consent.

dnc.name: None (no national DNC list; consumers rely on individual opt-outs)

sources.title: PIPA 2016 (Personal Information Protection Act); Electronic Communications Act 2011; PrivCom Telemarketing Guidance 2025

BS.callerid_rules: No dedicated telemarketing prefix. Caller ID should not be withheld (general requirement to identify caller or no spoofing)
BS.recent_changes: Revised consumer protection regulations were introduced around 2013 (no major recent changes). No new telemarketing laws in 2024; pending data privacy improvements have been discussed but not enacted
BS.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing is governed by consumer protection regulations (via URCA) and the Data Protection (Privacy of Personal Information) Act 2003. The Utilities Regulation & Competition Authority has rules for unsolicited calls, and individuals have a right to opt out of marketing use of their data
BS.regime_b2b_text: No specific B2B telemarketing law. B2B calls are generally permitted unless they involve personal data of individuals (then general privacy principles apply)
BS.notes_for_product: No DNC list – maintain an internal opt-out list. Obtain express consent for automated calls. Adhere to typical calling hours (e.g., 8am–9pm) as a best practice. Provide identification and honor any 'do not call' immediately. Enforcement of rules is limited, but reputational risk remains.

dnc.name: None (no national do-not-call registry; no official opt-out list beyond ad hoc requests)

sources.title: Consumer Protection (URCA) consultation 2013 (telemarketing section); Data Protection Act 2003 (right to prohibit direct marketing)

CU.callerid_rules: No specific telemarketing prefix. Calls from Cuba typically display Cuban numbers; the government telecom (ETECSA) manages numbering
CU.recent_changes: Cuba adopted a Social Communication Law in 2023, but it addresses media and propaganda, not telemarketing specifically. No indication of future telemarketing provisions
CU.regime_b2c_text: Telemarketing as a private business practice is extremely limited in Cuba. There are no known telemarketing-specific laws or consumer opt-in regimes. Communications are tightly controlled by the state; any sales calls would require state authorization
CU.regime_b2b_text: No framework for B2B telemarketing (private enterprise is heavily regulated; business calls would follow general communications rules)
CU.notes_for_product: Telemarketing activities in Cuba are not advised. Treat all calls as highly sensitive. If any outreach is needed, coordinate with Cuban authorities/ETECSA and assume full consent is needed from contacts.

sources.title: Official denial of any call-recording regulation (Supreme Court statement, 2025)

GF.quiet_hours: Mon–Fri 10:00–13:00 and 14:00–20:00; no calls on weekends or holidays
GF.callerid_rules: Yes – as of Jan 2023, telemarketing calls must use certain number ranges (France has reserved prefixes like 0162…0378 for marketing calls). Caller ID must not be concealed
GF.recent_changes: Very significant: Law of June 2025 prohibits unsolicited calls in specific sectors (effective July 2025) and will extend to all sectors by Aug 2026, moving France toward opt-in only. New hours and number prefix rules came into force in 2023
GF.regime_b2c_text: As an overseas department of France, French Guiana follows French and EU telemarketing laws. Telemarketing to consumers is tightly regulated under the French Consumer Code and GDPR. Cold calls are allowed only on an opt-out basis (Liste Bloctel) with strict time windows and upcoming shifts to opt-in
GF.regime_b2b_text: Calls to professionals are generally not covered by Bloctel rules (the French system applies to consumer (B2C) numbers only). B2B calls remain opt-out (permitted unless the business objects)
GF.notes_for_product: Full French compliance: must integrate Bloctel scrubbing before dialing any French Guiana numbers. Only call within permitted hours. Configure caller ID to an approved range. Starting 2026, require prior consent for essentially all cold calls – plan to switch to opt-in outreach. Recording requires verbal two-party consent on the call.

sources.title: Ministry of Economy (France) – Bloctel guidance; French Consumer Code (Bloctel exceptions); ARCEP number plan (2023)

GP.callerid_rules: Yes (must use French-assigned telemarketing numbers/prefixes starting 2023)
GP.recent_changes: French 2023–2025 changes (hours, prefix, upcoming ban by 2026) apply via local adoption
GP.regime_b2c_text: Guadeloupe is an overseas region of France, so French telemarketing laws apply (see French Guiana). Consumer telemarketing is tightly regulated: opt-out regime via Bloctel, limited call hours, and a transition toward opt-in by 2026
GP.regime_b2b_text: Same as mainland France: B2B calls are not covered by Bloctel. B2B telemarketing is permitted unless the business has objected
GP.notes_for_product: Complete alignment with France's regime. Scrub Guadeloupe phone numbers via Bloctel. Only call during allowed hours. Use French-approved caller IDs. Plan for opt-in only policies ahead of 2026.

sources.title: French Consumer Code (Bloctel); ARCEP decision on numbering (2022)

GU.quiet_hours: No calls before 8:00 am or after 9:00 pm local time
GU.callerid_rules: Yes – telemarketers must transmit a valid caller ID number that isn't blocked. (No special prefix; however, Guam numbers use country code +1 like U.S.)
GU.recent_changes: FCC/FTC are continuously updating rules to combat robocalls (e.g., STIR/SHAKEN implemented). In 2023, FTC amended the TSR to ban certain payment methods and tighten lead generation (effective 2024). These apply to Guam as a U.S. territory
GU.regime_b2c_text: U.S. telemarketing laws apply in Guam (a U.S. territory). The FTC/FCC rules under the Telephone Consumer Protection Act and Telemarketing Sales Rule govern calls. Consumers are protected by the National Do Not Call Registry and TCPA regulations (e.g., no calls outside 8am–9pm, consent for autodialed/prerecorded calls to cell phones)
GU.regime_b2b_text: Business numbers are generally not covered by the National DNC rules (the U.S. list is for residential numbers). Telemarketing to businesses is allowed, aside from FCC anti-fraud/spam norms
GU.notes_for_product: Guam phone numbers are part of NANP, so include them in U.S. compliance processes. Always check scrubbed lists against the national DNC. Implement time-of-day call blocks outside 8am-9pm. Ensure your dialing system accounts for Guam's time zone. Obtain express written consent for any autodialed or prerecorded marketing calls (especially to mobile numbers).

dnc.name: U.S. National Do Not Call Registry

sources.title: 47 CFR §64.1200 (TCPA rules); FTC Q&A on DNC (established relationship and exemptions)

VI.quiet_hours: No calls before 8 AM or after 9 PM local time
VI.callerid_rules: Yes – cannot block caller ID; must transmit a number/name that identifies the caller or seller. (No special prefix in the USVI; they use NANP area code 340.)
VI.recent_changes: Ongoing US efforts to combat robocalls (STIR/SHAKEN call authentication now required for VoIP providers). FTC in 2023 updated TSR to strengthen rules on deceptive marketing practices (effective 2024-25). These apply fully in USVI
VI.regime_b2c_text: As a U.S. territory, the USVI falls under the same federal telemarketing laws (TCPA and TSR). Consumers can join the National DNC Registry. Telemarketers must comply with calling time restrictions, identification requirements, and obtain consent for autodialed/prerecorded calls to wireless numbers
VI.regime_b2b_text: US DNC rules do not cover calls to businesses. B2B telemarketing is generally allowed, subject to general truth-in-advertising and do-not-call if the business number is actually a personal line
VI.notes_for_product: USVI is treated like any US state under the law: ensure scrub against DNC, call only 8am-9pm Atlantic Time, and implement opt-out and consent requirements for automated calls. Include USVI numbers in US compliance (they share +1 country code and are included in the National DNC Registry's area codes).

sources.title: FCC TCPA Regulations; FTC Telemarketing Sales Rule Q&A
